However, cessation must be attained through the power of the path. What is the nature of this path by which one attains it?
Verse:
It has already been said that afflictions are eliminated through seeing the truths and cultivation.
The path of seeing is only pure, while the path of cultivation is of two kinds.
Discussion:
It has already been extensively explained that the elimination of afflictions is due to the path of seeing the truths and the path of cultivation.
Is the path only pure or also contaminated?
It should be known that the path of seeing is only pure, while the path of cultivation is of two kinds.
Why is this so?
Because the path of seeing can quickly eliminate the three realms,
and because it suddenly eliminates the nine grades of afflictions to be eliminated by seeing, the worldly path does not have this capacity. Therefore, in the stage of seeing, the path is only pure.
Because the path of cultivation is different, it is of two kinds. As it was said before, it is due to seeing the truths.ğŸ”½.
What are the characteristics of the truths that are seen?
Verse:
The four truths were already explained earlier, namely suffering, origination, cessation, and the path.
Their own nature is also so, in sequence according to direct realization.
Discussion:
There are four kinds of truths, their names were already explained earlier.
Where were they explained?
In the first chapter, in the section on distinguishing contaminated and uncontaminated dharmas.
How were they explained there?
The verse says:
The uncontaminated is called the noble path, this explains the truth of the path.
Discrimination-extinction is called disjunction, this explains the truth of cessation.
And suffering, origination, and the world, this explains the truths of suffering and origination.
Is the sequence of the four truths as explained there?
No, it is not so.
How is it?
Now, as listed:
One, suffering; two, origination; three, cessation; four, the path.
Are there also differences in the nature of the four truths?
No, it is not so.ğŸ”½
How is it?
The words â€œin the same wayâ€ are used to show that the four fruits are the same in substance as the four nirvedhabhÄgÄ«ya.
Why is the order of the four truths as it is?
They are set forth in the order in which they are realized. That is, the truth that is realized first is set forth first. If this were not so, then cause would be set forth before effect.
There are other dharmas that are set forth in the order in which they arise, such as the four foundations of mindfulness.
There are other dharmas that are set forth in the order in which they are practiced, such as the four right efforts.
That is, there is no fixed principle here. One first eliminates that which has already arisen and later prevents that which has not yet arisen. It is merely a matter of the convenience of expression.
Now, in the present text, the four truths are set forth in the order in which they are realized by yogins.
Why is the order of realization certain?
Because in the state of added effort, one contemplates in this order.
Why is the order of added effort certain?

That is, if there is a dharma that is the object of attachment and can cause affliction, in order to seek the cause of liberation, this dharma should be initially investigated. Therefore, practitioners first contemplate suffering during the stage of added effort, and suffering is precisely the truth of suffering.
Next, they further contemplate the cause of suffering.
They then contemplate the cause of suffering, and the cause is precisely the truth of accumulation.
Next, they further contemplate the cessation of suffering.
They then contemplate the cessation of suffering, and cessation is precisely the truth of cessation.
Later, they contemplate the path to the cessation of suffering.
They then contemplate the path to the cessation of suffering, and the path is precisely the truth of the path.
It is like first seeing an illness, then seeking the cause of the illness, continuing to think about the cure for the illness, and later seeking good medicine.
The sutras also give a simile for the sequence of the truths.
Which sutra speaks of this?
It is the Sutra of the Good Physician.
As that sutra says:
The king of physicians is said to possess four virtues that can extract poisonous arrows:
first, he knows well the condition of the illness; second, he knows well the cause of the illness; third, he knows well the cure for the illness; fourth, he knows well the good medicine.
The TathÄgata is also like this. As the great physician king, he truly understands suffering, its accumulation, its cessation, and the path.

Therefore, in the stage of added effort, he contemplates in this sequence. In the stage of direct realization, the sequence is also like this, because it is attracted and emitted by the power of added effort, just as a horse gallops freely after having observed the ground.
What does the term direct realization refer to?
One should know that it refers to the meaning of directly realizing equality.
For what reason is it said that this is only pure?
Because it directly faces and truly realizes the realm of nirvÄá¹‡a. This realization is truly pure, and therefore it is called correct.

One should know that in this context, the aggregates of grasping with the nature of effects are called the truth of suffering, and the aggregates of grasping with the nature of causes are called the truth of accumulation, because they are able to accumulate.
Therefore, the categories of causes and effects of suffering and accumulation are distinguished by name but not by substance.
The two truths of cessation and the path differ in substance. Why are they said to be holy truths in the scriptures?
Because they are truths for the holy ones, they are called holy.
How could this become false for those who are not holy?
They are truths for all, because their nature is not erroneous.
However, only the noble ones truly see them, not others. Therefore, the sÅ«tras only call them the noble truths.
They are not not-noble truths, because they are seen in an inverted manner.
As a verse says:
What the noble ones call pleasure, the non-noble ones call suffering;
What the noble ones call suffering, the non-noble ones call pleasure.
Other masters say:
The last two are only noble truths, while the other two are both noble and non-noble truths.
Only one part of feeling is the substance of suffering, the rest are not.
How can it be said that all contaminated activities are the truth of suffering?
A verse says:
Suffering is combined with the three kinds of suffering, as appropriate,
Pleasant, unpleasant, and the rest of contaminated activities.
The treatise says:
There are three kinds of suffering by nature: the nature of suffering suffering, the nature of suffering as activity, and the nature of suffering as change.
All impure conditioned dharmas, as appropriate, are united with these three kinds of suffering natures, and therefore they are all called the truth of suffering without error.
Among them, agreeable impure conditioned dharmas are united with the suffering of change, and therefore they are called suffering.
All disagreeable impure conditioned dharmas are united with the suffering of suffering, and therefore they are called suffering.
Except for these, the remaining impure conditioned dharmas are united with the suffering of conditioned existence, and therefore they are called suffering.
What are called agreeable, disagreeable, and the rest?

The three feelings of pleasure, etc., in order, by the power of the three feelings, cause the impure conditioned dharmas that accord with the feeling of pleasure, etc., to obtain the name of agreeable, etc.
Why is this?
If all feelings of pleasure are suffering by change,
as a scripture says:
All feelings of pleasure are pleasurable when they arise and pleasurable when they endure, but painful when they change. If all feelings of suffering are suffering by nature,
as a scripture says:
All feelings of suffering are painful when they arise and painful when they endure.
The nature of suffering of neither pleasure nor pain is established by the fact that it is produced by the activity of causes and conditions.
As a scripture says:
If it is impermanent, it is suffering.
The same is true of the various conditioned forces as they are related to feeling.
Other masters explain:
The nature of suffering of suffering is suffering itself, and so on, up to the nature of suffering of the conditioned forces is the conditioned forces themselves.

You should know that in this explanation, the agreeable and disagreeable are said to be the suffering of the aggregate of formations that is the suffering of suffering because they are not shared by all.
In reality, all conditioned forces are suffering because of the suffering of the conditioned, and this is only something that sages can observe and see.
Therefore there is a verse that says:
If a single eyelash is placed in the palm of the hand, one is unaware of it,
but if it is placed on the eyeball, it causes harm and discomfort.
The fool is like the palm of the hand, unaware of the eyelash of the suffering of the conditioned forces,
but the sage is like the eyeball, and on that account he generates extreme aversion and fear.
The aggregates of suffering in the AvÄ«ci hell are not as fearful to the ignorant as the aggregates of suffering in the highest heaven are to the saints.
The truth of the path should also be categorized as the suffering of the karmic forces, because it is a conditioned state.
The truth of the path is not suffering, because the characteristic of the suffering of the karmic forces is that of opposing the holy life.
The arising of the holy path does not oppose the holy life, because it is able to lead to the end of all suffering.

If one contemplates the quiescence of nirvÄá¹‡a in regard to all conditioned dharmas, it is also because one first sees that these dharmas are suffering and then contemplates their cessation as quiescence. Therefore the words ALL CONDITIONED refer only to the impure.
If it is admitted that there is happiness among all dharmas, why is it said only that suffering is a noble truth?
One interpretation is as follows:
Because happiness is slight.
It is like a heap of black beans with a few green beans mixed in. Because of the small number, the heap is called a heap of black beans.
What wise person would consider a boil to be happiness because of the slight happiness produced by pouring on water?
Another interpretation is that of the following verse:
Because it is able to be a cause of suffering, because it is able to accumulate all suffering,
Because there is suffering that hopes for it, pleasure is also said to be suffering.

In reality, it should be said that the sages observe that all existence and pleasure are suffering, because they are of the same taste as the suffering of change. For this reason, suffering is established as a truth, not pleasure.
How is it that one also observes pleasant feeling as suffering?
Because by nature it is impermanent and contrary to the holy mind.
When one observes form, etc., with the characteristic of suffering, the characteristic of suffering is not the same as the suffering of sensation.
Some say: Because pleasant feeling is a cause of suffering.
If the sages also observe it as suffering, this explanation is unreasonable. Being able to be a cause of suffering is the characteristic of the truth of origination. How is it related to suffering?
Moreover, when the sages are born in the form and formless realms, how can the thought of suffering arise in relation to them?
Those aggregates are not a cause of suffering.
Moreover, what is the use of the sutra's further statement of the suffering of the karmic forces?

If you regard pleasure as suffering by means of the contemplation of impermanence, how does the mode of activity of the contemplation of impermanence differ from that of the contemplation of suffering?
It is contemplated as impermanent because it is a dharma that arises and ceases. It is contemplated as suffering because it opposes the holy mind.
One only sees impermanence and knows that it opposes the holy mind, and therefore the mode of activity of impermanence can attract the mode of activity of suffering.
Other Buddhist schools hold the opinion that
there is definitely no real pleasure, and feeling is only suffering.
How do they know this?
Because of teachings and principles.
How is it known from teachings?
As the World-Honored One said:
All feelings are not non-suffering.
Also, a sutra says:
You should contemplate pleasure as suffering.
Also, a sutra says:
To regard suffering as pleasure is called a perversion.
How is it known from principles?
Because the causes of pleasure are all uncertain.

Clothing, food and drink, cold and heat, and so on are considered by sentient beings to be causes of pleasure. If one indulges in them excessively or at the wrong time, they can produce suffering and become causes of suffering, and so should not be causes of pleasure.
Even if they are not excessive or at the wrong time, they can still become causes of suffering and produce suffering.
Therefore, we know that clothing and so on are originally causes of suffering. When suffering increases, their characteristics become manifest.
The same is true of changing postures.
Also, when one is curing suffering, one gives rise to the perception of pleasure, and when suffering is easily removed, the perception of pleasure arises.

That is to say, if one is not oppressed by the suffering of hunger, thirst, cold, heat, fatigue, desire, and so on, one does not give rise to the perception of pleasure with regard to the causes of pleasure.

Therefore, fools mistakenly think that these [causes of pleasure] can produce pleasure in the midst of the heavy causes of suffering that are being cured, but there are no definitely ascertained causes of pleasure that can be produced.
Fools think of pleasure in the midst of easily removed suffering, just as when one shifts a heavy burden from one shoulder to the other.
Therefore feeling is only suffering, and there definitely is no real pleasure.
The masters of the Abhidharma say that pleasure really exists. This statement is reasonable.
How do we know this?
First, we should ask those who deny the existence of pleasure what they consider to be suffering.ğŸ”½If they say that it is oppression, since there is also comfort, pleasure should exist.
If they say that it is harm, since there is also benefit, pleasure should exist.
If they say that it is not desirable, since there is also what is desirable, pleasure should exist.
If they say that what is desirable is not really established, because when the holy ones are free from passion, what was desirable becomes undesirable again.
This is not so.
When the holy ones are free from passion, they regard what is desirable as undesirable from a different point of view.
That is to say, if there is a feeling that is desirable in its own characteristics, this feeling will never become undesirable.

However, when holy beings are free from passion, they detest feeling by means of other aspects, considering it a place of heedlessness, and that it is impermanent and subject to change, and therefore not lovable, because it is accomplished by means of extensive and great effort. It is not that its own characteristics are not lovable.
If its own substance were not lovable, then one would not generate love for it.

If one did not generate love for it, then when free from passion, holy beings would not contemplate pleasant feeling by means of other aspects and deeply detest it. Therefore, because of its own characteristics, there is a real pleasant feeling.
However, the World Honored One himself explains the meaning of the statement that all feelings are not non-suffering.
As a scripture says:
The Buddha said to Ä€nanda:
I say this secretly based on the fact that all conditioned things are impermanent and all conditioned things are subject to change.
All feelings are suffering. Therefore we know that this scripture does not speak this way based on the suffering of suffering.
If you say that feeling is suffering by intrinsic nature, why did Nanda ask:
The Buddha said in other scriptures that there are three feelings, namely, pleasant, painful, and neither painful nor pleasant.
On the basis of what hidden meaning did he say in this scripture that all feelings are suffering?
Nanda should have asked:
On the basis of what hidden meaning did he say that there are three feelings?
The World Honored One should have answered:
I spoke of three feelings on the basis of this hidden meaning.
Since there is no such question and answer in the scripture, therefore there are really three feelings by intrinsic nature.

Since the World Honored One said that he spoke with a hidden meaning when he said that all feelings are suffering, he has already shown that this scripture he spoke was spoken with a different intention and is not true definitive meaning.
Also, a scripture says, You should contemplate pleasant feeling as suffering. You should know that this scripture shows that pleasant feeling has two natures:
The first is the nature of pleasure, which means that this pleasant feeling, according to its own characteristics, is lovable.
The second is the nature of suffering, which means that according to a different perspective, it is also impermanent and subject to change.
However, when one views it as pleasure, it can become a bondage, because those who are attached to it savor its taste.
If one views it as suffering, it can lead to liberation, because those who view it in this way can become free from attachment.
The Buddha, because he sees that viewing it as suffering can lead to liberation, advises sentient beings to view pleasure as suffering.
How do we know that its own characteristic is pleasure?
As a verse says:
The Buddhas, the Perfectly Enlightened Ones, know that all conditioned things are impermanent,
And that what is conditioned is subject to change, therefore they say that all feelings are suffering.

Also, a sutra says that to regard suffering as pleasure is a perversion. This is said with a specific intention, because in the world, with regard to pleasant feelings and wonderful desires, which are only partially pleasurable, one always regards them as completely pleasurable, and thus one falls into perversion.
That is, all pleasant feeling, if considered from another point of view, also has the nature of suffering. However, because the world only considers it to be pleasant, it becomes a perversion.
The objects of the five desires have little pleasure and much suffering, yet because they are only considered to be pleasant, it becomes a perversion.
The same is true of existence, therefore this cannot prove that the principle of the existence of pleasant feeling is not established.
If the intrinsic nature of feeling is truly all suffering, what benefit is there in the Buddha's teaching of the three feelings?
If it is said that the World-Honored One speaks in accordance with worldly conventions, that is not correct reasoning.
Because the World-Honored One said: I secretly explain that there is no feeling that is not suffering.
And because he speaks of contemplating the five feelings as being in accordance with reality.
That is to say, a sutra says:
All the faculty of pleasure and all the faculty of joy should be known as both being pleasant feeling, and so on at length.
It is also said:

If one contemplates and sees these five faculties with right wisdom in accordance with reality, the three bonds are permanently severed, and so on at length.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Also, how does the Buddha, in accordance with worldly convention, distinguish three feelings from one suffering?

If you say that the world produces the three feelings of pleasure, etc., in accordance with the order of weak, medium, and strong suffering, and the Buddha speaks of pleasure, etc., in accordance with this,
this is not reasonable, because pleasure is also threefold. One should produce the feeling of strong pleasure, etc., in response to weak, etc., suffering.
Also, when one experiences pleasure produced from superior smells, tastes, and tangibles, what weak suffering is there that the world produces the feeling of pleasure in response to it?

If you admit that there is weak suffering at that time, then when that weak suffering has already ended and has not yet arisen, the world should produce the feeling of extreme pleasure at that time, because in this state, all suffering is completely absent.
The same is true when one is questioned about the experience of pleasure while enjoying sensual pleasures.

Also, when a weak feeling is present, it is admitted that the feeling is clear, strong, and can be grasped. When a medium feeling is present, it is admitted that it is the opposite of this. How can this be reasonable?
Also, because it is said that there is pleasure in the first three trance states, there must be weak suffering;
Since it is said that the above stages are abandoned, there must be suffering in the middle.
How could it be reasonable that the excellence of samÄdhi increases suffering?
Therefore, the three kinds of feelings of pleasure, etc., should not be established in order according to the three kinds of suffering of pain, etc.
Moreover, a scripture says:
The Buddha said to MahÄnÄma:
If form were only suffering and not pleasure, not something that accompanies pleasure, and so on at length.
Therefore we know that there is definitely a small amount of real pleasure.
This is the explanation of how the scriptures they cite to show that there is no real pleasure are not established as evidence. The reasoning they offer is also not established as evidence.
As for the claim that the causes of pleasure are all indeterminate, this is not correct reasoning, because it is confused about the meaning of cause.
That is, observing the differences in the states of the basis, external objects then become causes of pleasure or causes of suffering. They are not only external objects.

If these external objects reach this state of the basis and can be causes of pleasure, they have never reached this state and are not causes of pleasure. Therefore the causes of pleasure are not indeterminate.
Just as when one observes the differences in the state of what is being cooked or roasted, it is the cause of good cooking or it is not the cause of good cooking, and it is not only the fire.

If this fire reaches this state of what is being cooked or roasted, it is the cause of good cooking, and it never reaches this state as a non-cause of good cooking. Therefore, the cause of good cooking is not indeterminate.
The cause of pleasure is also like this, and the principle of determination is established.
Moreover, is the cause of pleasure in the three meditations not indeterminate?
Because that cause never produces suffering.
Moreover, as for what they say, that when one must cure suffering one produces the perception of pleasure, this has already been refuted above.

That is, when one experiences pleasure produced by the superior flavors, smells, and touches, what suffering does it cure, such that the world produces the perception of pleasure in the midst of this?

Even if one admits that at that time one cures gross suffering, this suffering that is being cured has already ceased and has not yet been produced. At that time, one should produce the perception of extreme pleasure.
Moreover, what does the pleasure of the meditations cure, such that it is produced?
Refutations such as these should be explained according to the above.

Also, they say that when suffering is easily removed, a feeling of pleasure arises, as when one shifts the weight from one shoulder to the other. This bodily condition is really able to produce pleasure. As long as the body is in such a condition, pleasure will definitely arise before it ceases. If it ceases, then it will not.

Also, they say that when suffering is easily removed, a feeling of pleasure arises, as when one shifts the weight from one shoulder to the other. This state of the body is really able to produce pleasure. As long as the body is in this state, pleasure will definitely arise before it ceases. If it were not so, then pleasure would increase in the subsequent state, because suffering would gradually diminish.
In the same way, it should be understood that pleasure arises when the four deportments of the body are easily changed and when fatigue is relieved.
If suffering did not exist previously, why would a feeling of suffering suddenly arise at the end?
Because the state of the body changes, just as the taste of wine and so on becomes sweet or sour at a later time. Therefore it is reasonable to conclude that the feeling of pleasure really exists.
Therefore, it is definitely known that all impure conditioned dharmas are called suffering because they are associated with the three kinds of suffering.

The essence of the activity of suffering is also called the truth of the origin of suffering. This explanation definitely contradicts the scriptures, because the scriptures say that craving alone is the origin.
The scriptures speak of craving as the origin because it is the most important. In reality, the other impure dharmas are also the truth of the origin.
By what is this principle known?
Because other scriptures also say it is so.
As the BhagavÄn said in a verse:
Karma, craving, and ignorance are the causes that attract subsequent activities,
Causing the continuity of existence, called the pudgala.
Also, a scripture speaks of five kinds of seeds, which are the same as the consciousness that grasps existence.
Also, that scripture says they are placed in the earth element, which is the same as the four abodes of consciousness.
Therefore, what is said in the scriptures is of implied meaning, while the Abhidharma teaches according to the characteristics of dharmas.
However, the scriptures say craving is the origin in order to explain the cause of arising.
The verse says karma, craving, and ignorance are all causes in order to fully explain the cause of birth and the cause of arising.
How do we know this?ğŸ”½Because karma is the cause of birth and craving is the cause of arising, as the scriptures say.
Also, that scripture shows in sequence that subsequent karma has causes, conditions, and roots.

The seeds and the field are established separately, and the consciousness that appropriates and the four abodes of consciousness are taught. Therefore craving is not the only reality of the truth of the origin.ğŸ”½What is birth?
What is arising?
The appearance of the body of the various kinds of beings, such as the realms, destinies, and forms of birth, is called birth.
If there is no distinction, the continuation of subsequent existence is called arising.

Karma and craving for existence are the causes of those two, respectively, just as a seed is the cause that produces the sprouts of the various kinds of grains, such as rice and wheat, and water is the cause that produces the sprouts of all kinds without distinction. You should understand that karma and craving for existence are also like this as causes of birth and arising.
What is the evidence that craving is the cause of arising?
Because subsequent existence definitely does not arise apart from craving.
That is to say, both those with craving for existence and those without craving for existence die, but only those with craving for existence are seen to give rise to subsequent existence.
This reasoning proves that craving is the cause of arising, because arising or not arising definitely follows craving.
Also, because of craving, the continuum proceeds to a later existence. It is seen that where there is craving, the mindâ€™s continuum often proceeds there.
From this, we infer that because there is craving, it can cause the continuum to proceed to a later existence.

Moreover, there is no other dharma that firmly grasps and clings to a later body like craving. It is like jujube powder mixed with water and applied to the body when bathing. When it dries, it sticks to the body and is difficult to remove. Nothing else can compare.
In the same way, there is no other cause that grasps and takes a later body like craving for self. From this reasoning, we prove that craving is the cause of arising.
Thus the World-Honored One has said that there are four truths.
Other sÅ«tras also say:
There are two kinds of truths: first, conventional truth, and second, ultimate truth.
What are the characteristics of these two truths?
The verse says:
When that cognition is destroyed, it no longer exists. When wisdom analyzes the rest, it is also like this.
Like a pot or water, it is conventional. Different from this, it is called ultimate.
The treatise states:
If the cognition of an object ceases when it is destroyed, that object should be known as conventional truth.
When a pot is destroyed and reduced to shards, the cognition of a pot ceases. Clothing and so forth are also like this.

Moreover, if an object is analyzed by wisdom and the cognition of it ceases, it is also conventional, like water. When water is analyzed by wisdom into form and so forth, the cognition of water ceases. Fire and so forth are also like this.
When an object has not yet been destroyed or analyzed, it is designated by the names of worldly conventions as that. Because of the designation, it is called conventional.
Relying on the conventional principle, it is said that pots and so forth exist. This is real and not false, and is called conventional truth.
If an object is different from this, it is called ultimate truth.

That is to say, if the cognition of an object does not cease when it is destroyed, and if the cognition of it still exists when it is analyzed by wisdom, one should know that object to be ultimate truth.

When form and so on is reduced to atoms or is analyzed by wisdom into taste and so on, the awareness of form and so on still occurs. The same is so of feeling and so on. This is real and is therefore called ultimate.
Relying on the principle of the ultimate, it is said that form and so on exist and is not false, and this is called ultimate truth.
The ancient masters have said,
The dharmas grasped by supramundane knowledge and by the subsequently acquired mundane knowledge are called ultimate truth, while those grasped by other knowledge are called conventional truth.
Having discussed the various truths, we must now discuss the method of diligent practice that leads to the path of seeing the truths.
A verse says:
In order to enter the path of seeing the truths, one should abide in morality and diligently cultivate
Learning, reflection, and cultivation, which have as their objects names, words, and concepts,
The treatise says:
Those who arouse the aspiration to enter the path of seeing the truths should first abide in pure morality and then diligently cultivate learning, reflection, and so on.

That is, first one accepts the teachings that accord with the truth of the path. Having heard them, one diligently seeks the teachings and their meanings. Having heard the teachings and their meanings, one reflects on them without error. Having reflected, one is then able to cultivate them in accordance with samÄdhi.

The practitioner, abiding in the precepts and diligently cultivating, gives rise to the wisdom born of reflection based on the wisdom born of hearing. Based on the wisdom born of reflection, one gives rise to the wisdom born of cultivation.
What are the differences in the characteristics of these three wisdoms?
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say that the characteristics of the three wisdoms are distinguished by their objects, which are names, both names and meanings, and meanings, respectively.
The wisdom born of hearing only takes names as its object, because it has not yet been able to abandon the text while contemplating the meaning.

The wisdom born of reflection takes both names and meanings as its objects, because sometimes the meaning is elicited by the text and sometimes the text is elicited by the meaning. It has not yet completely abandoned the text while contemplating the meaning.
The wisdom born of cultivation only takes meanings as its objects, because it has already been able to abandon the text and only contemplates the meaning.

It is like a person floating on a deep, swift-flowing river. One who has never learned does not let go of what they rely on. One who has learned but is not yet proficient may let go or cling. One who has learned well does not need to rely on anything and can float across by their own power.
The three wisdoms are also like this.
Some say:
If that is so, then the wisdom of reflection is not established.
This is because it is said to be able to take names and meanings as objects. It should be the wisdom accomplished through hearing and cultivation, respectively.

Now, examining the three characteristics without fault, it is said that the practitioner's superior wisdom born from hearing the teachings is called that accomplished through hearing. The superior wisdom born from contemplating the correct principles is called that accomplished through reflection. The superior wisdom born from cultivating meditative absorption is called that accomplished through cultivation.

The words accomplished show that these three superior wisdoms are accomplished through the three causes of hearing, reflection, etc., just as in the world, life, cows, etc. are said to be accomplished through food and grass, respectively.
For those who wish to diligently study cultivation, how do they purify the body and mind so that cultivation can be quickly accomplished?
Verse:
Endowed with physical and mental seclusion, without insufficiency or great desire,
Referring to what is already obtained and what is not yet obtained, seeking much is what is not.
The characteristics of the antidotes are the three realms, and the nature is without greed,
The four noble lineages are also like this, the first three are only contented.
The last is action, in order to counteract the arising of the four attachments,
The desire for self and things of self, temporarily ceasing and forever eliminating.
The treatise says:
The purification of the body and mind is briefly due to three causes.
What are the three causes?
First, physical and mental seclusion, second, contentment and few desires, third, abiding in the four noble lineages.
Physical seclusion means being apart from mixed dwelling.
Mental seclusion means being apart from unwholesome thoughts.
These two are easy to accomplish, due to contentment and few desires.
Contentment means being without discontentment, and few desires means being without great desires.
What are the differences between the two that are absent?
The Abhidharma masters all say:
Seeking more of already obtained fine clothing and so on is called discontent, and seeking much of not yet obtained clothing and so on is called great desire.
Isn't seeking more also conditioned by what is not yet obtained? Then the distinction between these two would not be established.
Therefore, here it should be said:

Discontent with what has already been obtained as not fine or not much, and not rejoicing is called discontent. Seeking fineness and much in clothing and so on that has not yet been obtained is called great desire.
Because contentment and few desires can counteract these, their distinctions should be known as opposed to these.
Contentment and few desires are common to the three realms and are pure, while their counteragents are only bound to the desire realm.
